concept.name: Frame
concept.description: A frame is a schematic representation of a situation involving various participants, props, and other conceptual roles, each of which is a frame element

concept.name: Frame Element
concept.description: The semantic roles of a frame, the linguistic realization of which highlights different participants (or semantic roles) of a frame

concept.name: Core Frame Element
concept.description: The roles of a frame that are essential to its meaning.

concept.name: Non-Core Frame Element
concept.description: The non-essential roles of a frame. Non-core FEs are generally descriptive (such as time, place, manner, etc.).

concept.name: Frame Definition
concept.description: A textual description of what the frame represents.

concept.name: Lexical Unit
concept.description: The lemmas, with their part of speech, that evoke a specific frame. Pairing between a lemma and a frame.

concept.name: Frame Relation
concept.description: Relations capture relationships between different frames

concept.name: Example sentences
concept.description: The example sentences of a frame.

concept.name: Valence
concept.description: The range of semantic and syntactic combinatory possibilities. The particular kinds of constituents, in terms of semantic roles, grammatical functions, and phrase t/ypes, with which a word combines in a grammatical sentence. The number and the position of the frame elements within example sentences. Semantico-syntactic combinatorial possibilities â—¦meaning-form-function mappings. FrameNet valence:

concept.name: Annoset
concept.description: Annotation set. The assignment of semantic role tags to syntactic constituents.

examples.example: [We Agent] must avoid [jumping to conclusions Undesirable_situation].
[Young people Agent] can avoid [getting into trouble Undesirable_situation].

concept.name: GF
concept.description: Grammatical Function. Describes the ways in which constituents in a sentence satisfy abstract grammatical requirements of the target word.
